CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 24, 1961, pg. 1 reads: "No More Shade...Only A Stump Remains - Apparently, some Braddock Borough officials think, like those un-Americans down in Mississippi and Georgia, that a tree is to be used, where Negroes are concerned, for lynching." is the consensus of opinion of these angry Braddock citizens, as Willie Carpenter points to all that remains of a shade tree - a STUMP! Because it afforded shade, the citizens said that some of their number built some tables and benches for use by elderly people and mothers who desired to sit and watch (as a safety precaution) their children at play nearby.  However, they added, some borough officials "objected to this, and ordered the tree cut down."  They warned that the act may have political repercussions. - Harris Photo."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of sixteen men, two women, and child, standing around tree stump with plaque in empty lot, corner of 11th Street and Talbot Avenue, Braddock, another version
